sen.j: 地奉行（じぶぎょう）とは、鎌倉幕府・室町幕府によって設置された奉行。
sen.e: Jibugyo was bugyo (magistrate) appointed by the Kamakura bakufu and the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: それぞれの本拠地であった鎌倉・京都の屋地に関する行政・裁判を行う。
sen.e: He was in charge of administration and trials related to houses and lands in Kamakura and Kyoto where the respective bakufu was located.

sen.e: He played a role similar to that of machi-bugyo (town magistrate) who was responsible for administration and trials related to houses and lands in Edo where the Edo bakufu was located.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の地奉行は、下部の役職である保奉行人とともに北条泰時によって整備されたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that in the Kamakura period, Yasutoki HOJO appointed Jibugyo together with Hobugyonin (person who monitors and polices for villains and street trades), a low-level position.

sen.j: 侍所の管轄下に属し、侍所とともに鎌倉の行政と治安維持にあたっていた。
sen.e: Placed under the Samurai-dokoro (the Board of Retainers), they took on the administration and maintenance of public order of Kamakura with the Samurai-dokoro.

sen.j: しかし、実際には奉行のうち最低1名は御内人から選ばれており、得宗及び執権による支配が鎌倉市中にまで浸透していたと考えられている。
sen.e: However, in reality, at least one bugyo was selected from Miuchibito (private vassals of the tokuso), and it is considered that control by the Tokuso (the patoromonial head of the main branch of the Hojo clan) and the regent spread to the city of Kama,kura.

sen.cmt: 得宗 補足を移動しました。

sen.j: 室町幕府の地奉行は、地方頭人（じかたとうにん）と呼ばれて下に開闔・寄人などの地方役人が置かれていた。
sen.e: Jibugyo in the Muromachi period was called Jikatatonin (a head of Jikata, a person in charge of trials related to houses and lands), and local officials such as Kaiko (assistant administrator) and Yoriudo (a dependent, frequently one who served a noble house or proprietor) were placed under them.

Jibugyo of the Muromachi bakufu was called Jikatatonin (a head of Jikata, a person in charge of trials related to housing and land), and local officials such as Kaigo (assistant administrator) and Yoriudo (staff that worked at bakufu organizations) were placed under them.

sen.e: Placed under the jurisdiction of Samurai-dokoro, they took on the administration and maintenance of public order of Kyoto with the Samurai-dokoro.

sen.j: しかし、実際には朝廷の検非違使と権限が重複したため、度々衝突した。
sen.e: However, in reality, they often clashed with the kebiishi (a police and judicial chief) of the Imperial court because their authorities overlapped.

sen.j: だが、足利義満の時代に室町幕府が京都市中の支配権を完全に掌握すると、検非違使は事実上廃止されて地奉行に権限が一本化された。
sen.e: But once the Muromachi bakufu took total control of the city of Kyoto in Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA's day, the post of kebiishi was virtually abolished and the authority was granted to jibugyo exclusively.
